title: Ticket #7594: Efficiently close FDs after fork
description: See parent ticket for details. Splitting this ticket across a code freeze.
remarks:
2020-Apr-10 15:27:21 by tlmiller:
Implementing a libbsd-style fix make be too radical for the stable series.

2020-Apr-14 13:09:14 by tlmiller:
The V8_9-gt7594-branch appears to work. Asking for a review both for code quality (we really don't want to screw this up) and to determine if the change is safe for the stable series (probably not).

2020-Apr-14 13:44:32 by jfrey:
Code Review

This code will attempt to close the FD associated with the DIR object. It happens after closedir(), so is harmless. I don't think a change is needed.

Otherwise, this looks good.

As mentioned already, not recommended for the stable series.

2020-Apr-14 13:55:14 by bbockelm:
Thoughts:

  1. Factor this out into a library call. We're going to want it later for Create_Process.
  2. This might fail if /proc isn't mounted inside a container or if HTCondor is already at its ulimit for fds. Needs a fallback.
  3. I'm a bit nervous to buffer a vector of all fds. What about having it break every 1K close() invocations and reopen the directory? As long as we are making forward progress...

2020-Apr-14 14:16:43 by tlmiller:
Jaime: We could call dirfd() to avoid close()ing that FD redundantly, but I'm not sure which way is faster.

1. Agreed, but it seemed a good idea to get it reviewed first.

2. I feel like not mounting /proc should break all sorts of things, but fair enough, if the rest of HTCondor works without it, we should have a fallback.

3. I guess if we avoided closing the dir FD, that would work, and I guess a fixed-size buffer would be faster anyway.

Thanks for the feedback, both of you.

2020-Apr-15 08:22:09 by bbockelm:
Revisions look much better. I also noticed we don't have much sanity checking for the strtol call; it might be worthwhile to check errno and that the value is positive (perhaps switching to std::stol while we're at it).k

Again, mostly paranoia -- but sometimes paranoia is OK too.

2020-Apr-15 11:33:18 by tlmiller:
I think that the endptr check handles the only case we care about - did we convert the whole filename into an int or not, and even that's being really paranoid. If the kernel suddenly spazzes out and drops non-numeric names or negative numbers in /proc/self/fds, I think we have other problems.

I suppose somebody could have not mounted /proc and filled self/fds with garbage? Do we care about that case?

I'd rather not use std::stol() and have to deal with exceptions.

2020-Apr-15 11:34:06 by tlmiller:
I have a patch to close only 1024 FDs at a time, but I don't like it (it involves cleverness to detect when we're done). How strongly do we feel about that?

2020-Apr-20 15:28:35 by bbockelm:
Heh: exceptions, that's the reason why I prefer the std version of the function :)

I'll let you be the judge on whether buffering the file descriptors is worthwhile. If it's too much complexity, I agree it can be skipped.

2020-Apr-20 15:37:32 by tlmiller:
According to BrianB, for clone(), we can't call opendir() or readdir() before the exec, or allocate memory, so we'll have to have a version where the list of FDs is populated in the parent and passed into the child. (Which renders an attempt to only close() 1024 at a time meaningless.)
